metadata.title: Cerebral Palsy  Occupational Therapy •In the United States, depending on geographical location, individuals with CP might be eligible for state government-funded  therapy programs in the school, clinic, or home setting. Evaluations to determine if a child qualifies for early intervention services through a state-funded  program are free to recipients. Children under the age of 3 years are evaluated by local early intervention services. If the child is 3 years of age or older, the evaluation is through the local public school system •No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
anatomical location body part affected: Cerebral palsy (CP) results from a lesion in the developing brain affecting the development of the total child, primarily the CNS and musculoskeletal system. The presentation of involvement of body segments may manifest differently as a child grows and develops
description: CP describes a complex group of persistent nonprogressive disorders of central origin involving movement or posture and motor function,including spasticity, dyskinesia, hypotonia, and ataxia, that occur due to damaged brain tissue from various perinatal or neonatal causes. Motor impairments are frequently accompanied by multiple comorbid conditions, including vision and hearing deficits, cognitive disabilities, and seizure disorders(51,52,53)
CP is the most common motor disability in childhood(31)

There are three different systems,anatomic, physiologic, and functional,by which CP can be classified. They can be combined to assess lesion location and severity, make treatment decisions, and predict functional outcome(51,52,53)

Anatomic classification(51,52,53) –Anatomic classification may assist with localization of underlying anomaly or injury –Assesses distribution of involvement -Monoplegia: one extremity involved (rare) -Diplegia: lower extremities more affected than upper extremities -Hemiplegia: one side of the body more affected and upper extremities usually more than lower extremities -Quadriplegia: all four limbs affected, upper extremities usually more affected, and trunk and orofacial muscles may also be involved -Other designations may include -paraplegia: lower half of body affected, including both legs -triplegia: three limbs are affected -double hemiplegia: all four limbs affected, but greater on one side and often with the upper extremities affected more than lower extremities -tetraplegia: all four limbs affected, may be greater in three limbs (not used in a consistent manner in the literature)

Physiologic classification(51,52,53) –Physiologic classification may assist in assessing function and planning treatment –Assesses quality of muscle function and motor impairment -Spastic/pyramidal (present in 80–90%  of persons with CP) -Hypertonia with resistance to externally imposed movement with one or more of the following  -increases with increasing speed of stretch -varies with direction of joint movement -rises rapidly above a threshold speed or joint angle -Spasticity is combined with anatomic classification into specific types -Spastic diplegia -Spastic quadriplegia -Spastic hemiplegia -Nonspastic/extrapyramidal -Hypotonia with decreased or variable muscle tone -Results in loose, floppy limbs -Movement can be slow or fast, repetitive, and sometimes rhythmic -Planned movements can result in intention tremors, which increase with stress and resolve during sleep -May have increased reflexes and Babinski response -Nonspastic CP is divided into two groups -Ataxic: inability to coordinate voluntary muscular movements due to abnormal force, rhythm, and accuracy, including -impairment of coordinated movements such as balance and posture -wide or irregular walking gait -impairment of eye movements and depth perception -poor fine motor skills -Dyskinetic: collective term for several involuntary movement disorders, including -chorea: abrupt, jerky, nonrhythmic distal movements without pattern -athetosis: slow, writhing, continuous movements in the extremities -dystonia: twisting and repetitive movements with or without abnormal postures -usually associated with some spasticity -Mixed forms are frequent

Functional classification(51,52,53) –Functional classification assesses function and limitations in activity -The most used functional classification system is the Gross Motor Classification System (GMFCS) -The child is classified into one of five levels based on ability to ambulate and level of independence -GMFCS classification applied to an infant is likely to change up until age 2, after which it stabilizes

Statistics vary per country –Researchers looking at the birth prevalence of spastic CP in a heterogeneous U.S. metropolitan area from 1985 to 2002 determined a prevalence of 1.9 per 1,000 1-year  survivors. They also concluded that CP prevalence was stable, which was encouraging given improvements in neonatal survival. However, the persistence of higher CP prevalence among non-Hispanic  Blacks when compared to non-Hispanic  Whites was concerning(38)

In the United States, depending on geographical location, individuals with CP might be eligible for state government-funded  therapy programs in the school, clinic, or home setting. Evaluations to determine if a child qualifies for early intervention services through a state-funded  program are free to recipients. Children under the age of 3 years are evaluated by local early intervention services. If the child is 3 years of age or older, the evaluation is through the local public school system
No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Limited passive joint mobility, soft tissue contractures(2,5)
Altered motor control (i.e., athetosis, dyskinesia, ataxia)(2)
Poor postural alignment (i.e., scoliosis, equinovalgus deformity)(2,5)
Abnormal tone, spasticity, hypertonia or hypotonia
Feeding/growth issues –Oropharyngeal dysphagia –Oral motor dysfunction(3) –Foregut dysmotility(3) –Failure to thrive(4)

Associated conditions –Seizure disorders(36) –Visual impairments such as retinopathy of prematurity,(34) high myopia, dyskinetic strabismus, severe gaze dysfunction, optic neuropathy, cerebral visual impairment –Sensorineural hearing loss(34) –Gastrointestinal/nutritional problems such as esophageal dysmotility, gastroesophageal reflux, delayed gastric emptying, constipation, hiatal hernia, esophagitis –Sialorrhea (drooling) –Dental problems such as enamel erosion and malocclusion –Respiratory problems such as recurrent pneumonia, atelectasis, bronchiectasis, restrictive lung disease –Urology problems such as incontinence, urgency, frequency, difficulty with initiating void, retention, infection –Cognitive impairment/learning disabilities/attention deficits(4) –Psychosocial impairments such as low self-esteem  issues, anxiety disorders, depression, emotional dysregulation, psychosis(4) –Sleep abnormalities(34) – e.g., obstructive sleep apnea, parasomnia, night wakings, sleep anxiety Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Persons with developmental disabilities may be at risk for falls. Always maintain patient safety and follow facility protocols for risk prevention during evaluation and treatment sessions
Follow facility protocols for obtaining parental consent

causes: Congenital CP – occurs as a result of injury to the child’s brain prior to or during the birthing process–85–90%  of CP cases are congenital(31)–Causes of CP(6)-Birth asphyxia-Prematurity-Atypical intrauterine growth – babies who are small or large at birth for their gestational ages have an increased risk forCP-Infection (such as toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes virus, hepatitis B virus, syphilis, HIV , group Bstreptococcus), inflammation, and maternal fever in labor-In a study, the babies of women with fever during labor were 7 times more likely to have CP than babies of womenwithout fevers(6)-Perinatal ischemic stroke-Congenital anomalies-Multiple gestation-Twins are at greater risk for having CP than singletons-Multiples are more likely to be premature-In multiple births, if one infant dies in utero a vascular collapse in the surviving fetus can occur, resulting in congenitalanomalies(6)-Placental pathology-Chorioamnionitis can increase risk of CP, especially if inflammation is present-Chronic villitis-Genetics-Genetic variants of inflammatory cytokines, apolipoprotein E variant, and possibly nitric oxide synthase have beenlinked to increased CP risk-Neonatal encephalopathy-Intracranial hemorrhage(1)

Acquired CP – occurs as a result of injury to the brain after birth, up to the first few years of the life (typically by age 2years)–~ 10% of cases of CP are acquired–Usually associated with an infection (e.g., meningitis) or head injury(31)

For spastic hemiplegic CP, the main causes are perinatal stroke and congenital malformations.(6) Other causes include anypathology that results in widespread bilateral damage to the brain, such as global hypoxicischemia(6)
For spastic diplegic CP, causes include intrauterine infection, premature rupture of membranes, and multiple gestations(6)
pathogenesis: Start of motor unit activation is slow and prolonged, which leads to reduced speed of movement and decreased forceproduction
Agonist and antagonist muscles co-contract  inappropriately, leading to decreased muscle strength(7)

Types of brain damage that can result in CP–Damage to the white matter of the brain, which can lead to periventricular leukomalacia (PVL)(1)–Cerebral dysgenesis (abnormal brain development) can interfere with brain signal delivery(1)–Intracranial hemorrhage, caused by faulty/blocked blood vessels(1)–Lack of oxygen can destroy tissue in the cerebral motor cortex and other areas of the brain(1)
risk factors: The National Institutefor Health and Care Excellence (NICE) considers the following risk factors sufficiently significant towarrant enhanced clinical and developmental follow-up(54)–Prenatal and perinatal factors-Preterm birth-Low birth weight-Chorioamnionitis-Neonatal encephalopathy-Neonatal sepsis–Postnatal factors-Meningitis

Additional risk factors–Risk factors for term and late preterm neonates-Low Apgar score (Apgar score < 10 at 5 or 10 minutes associated with increased risk of CP)(67)-Multiple gestation and in vitro fertilization (IVF)-Compared to singletons, reported relative risk of CP is 5.6 in twins and 12.6 in triplets(55)-Additional risk factors in multiple pregnancies(55)-Monochorionic pregnancy (shared amniotic sac)-Still birth of co-twin-Infant death of co-twin–Risk factors specific to preterm infants(52,53)-Periventricular leukomalacia-Intraventricular hemorrhage grade III and IV-Intracranial hemorrhage–Maternal overweight or obesity during early pregnancy is associated with increased risk of CP in children of women withsingleton pregnancies(68)–Affected sibling or parent increases risk of CP(69)

Genetic risk factors–One third to one half of children with CP lack traditional risk factors, which raises suspicion of potential geneticcontribution(52,54)–Gene variants have been implicated in small studies with limited validation–Genomic contribution to CP is likely to be very complex similar to other neurodevelopmental disorders such as autismand intellectual disability(70)

overall contraindications precautions: Clinicians should include the family/caregivers in the treatment sessions, explain and demonstrate therapeutic treatment interventions, and provide verbal and written instruction as indicated
Patients with CP are at increased risk for fractures. Clinicians must take appropriate precautions during occupational therapy to minimize the risk of injury

Based on a systematic review and meta-analysis,  children with disabilities are at least 3 times more likely to be abused or neglected than children without disabilities.(71)Report any suspected abuse
For patients who are nonambulatory, be aware of risk for pressure sores(52)

A patient with oral motor dysfunction may not be able to safely manage liquids/foods and may be at risk for aspiration.(9) Consult with family, nurse, and/or speech-language  pathologist (SLP) for diet and fluid restrictions
Patients with CP may be at risk for respiratory compromise that can limit ability to participate in therapeutic activity

Patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) can develop esophagitis. This can result in dystonic posturing of the head and neck, hematemesis or vomiting, anemia, or chronic irritability(34)
In patients with shunts, monitor for signs/symptoms of shunt malfunction (e.g., seizures, irritability, headaches, vomiting)(32)
Follow protocols for orthosis use; always check for redness or skin irritation
Children with developmental disabilities may be at risk for falls. Always maintain patient safety
Seizures are common in persons with CP. Clinicians should be aware of appropriate responses
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Obtain the birth history, including prenatal, perinatal, and postnatal periods -When was CP diagnosed? -What is the current reason for evaluation and treatment? -Has the child undergone any surgeries? If so, when? In the parents’ opinion, were they successful? -Inquire about any medical complications

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical procedures the patient has received to date Gastrostomy tube (GT) feeding if oral feeding is unsafe, nutrition cannot be maintained orally, or daily feeding time is prolonged(63) Selective dorsal rhizotomyfor decreasing spasticity(52) Selective dorsal rhizotomy appears effective for improving motor function in patients with spastic CP(72) Surgical interventions Surgery for muscle/tendon lengthening, tendon transfers, tendon release Surgery for positional deformities and/or joint abnormalities
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Does the patient and/or family feel the medications are effectively controlling symptoms? Medications used for treatment of spasticity may improve muscle function, reduce secondary complications such as joint contractures or other orthopedic disorders and pain, and alter natural history of CP to improve overall care and function. They include(52,53,55,73) Botulinum toxin A (BoNT-A) Baclofen Diazepam Most useful if rapid relief needed, especially at bedtime Effects are short-term  and sideeffect of muscle weakness may occur Tizanidine Medications used for the treatment of dystonia include(52,55) Intrathecal baclofen Anticholinergic or dopaminergic agents such as trihexyphenidyl, tetrabenazine, or carbidopa-levodopa Anti-epileptic  drugs (AEDs) for decreasing seizures(4) Side effects include mental health problems such as depression or psychosis(4)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed : Usual tests for this condition are the following:
MRI: can help determine etiology or clinical management and is preferred over CT scan(55)
X-Rays:  To assess hip and pelvis deformities(51)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational therapy, physical therapy, speech language therapy, or special education services for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much ) -Oucher Pain Scale  pain self-report  for children aged 3 years and older -FLACC (Face, Leg, Activity, Cry, and Consolability) pain assessment tool used for children; assesses facial expression, leg movement, activity, cry, and consolability
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Individuals with CP may experience a variety of sleep-disordered  breathing patterns that may affect function, behavior, and learning potential.Sleep can be affected as a result of sleep anxiety, night wakings, parasomnias, apnea, difficulty self-soothing,  epilepsy, and reduced melatonin secretion(34)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) -Ask about any back pain. Adults with CP are at risk for developing spondylolysis from stress fractures from repetitive hyperextension from dystonic movements; prevalence among adults with CP is 21% to 30%(5) -Ask about any neck pain, loss of bladder control, or upper extremity function, as cervical stenosis can also occur in adults with athetoid CP(5) -Ask about any arthritis or joint pain, as patients with CP may have osteoarthritic changes that can place patient at risk for hip displacement and fractures(4,5) -Ask about neurogenic bladder and constipation(5)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Ask about any respiratory problems. Children with spastic CP may have chronic respiratory issues(12) Barriers to learning Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask about achievement of developmental milestones up to this point
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask parents/caregivers/patient about other problems, including diabetes, gastrointestinal disease, learning impairments, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and respiratory problems
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document child’s participation in extracurricular activities and recreational or competitive sports
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any adaptive equipment used by patient and the amount of assistance patient requires for self-care  tasks
social and occupational history.living environment: Document who lives with the patient, the number of stairs in home, number of floors in home, any personal care assistance, and any bathroom modifications. Note if there has been a home safety evaluation performed and the modifications suggested. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home, community, or school and if any modifications are needed

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristicschildren with CP often have impaired growth(3) -Height may be difficult to assess in children with postural deformities. Can use upper arm length, tibial length, and/or knee height as alternative measures of linear growth(3) –BMI is not a good measure of body fat in children with CP –triceps skinfold thickness (TST) can be used instead. A TST below the 10th percentile indicates low body fat and undernutrition(3) –Body composition (fat, water, protein, and bone content) can be assessed using dual x-ray  absorptiometry (DXA)(3)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess need for assistive/adaptive equipment for self-care tasks. Assess need for mobility devices, such as walker, wheelchair, or electric wheelchair, specialized seating, or pressure-relieving  cushions
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Assess trunk control/balance in sitting and standing. Impaired trunk control can negatively impact the patient’s standing, sitting balance, and ambulation. Note whether the patient’s righting and equilibrium reactions are intact and effective, impaired, or absent(8) –Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)  balance subtest, Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)  balance subtest, or Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Document patient’s activity tolerance or need for frequent rest breaks
Document vital signs at rest, during activity, and post activity •Ergonomics/body mechanics
Assess child’s body mechanics; note any postural instability or postural compensatory movements
Assess parent/caregiver’s body mechanics when assisting/transferring patient •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.)

Assess functional mobility within patient’s environment: home, school. Assess ADL transfers (toilet/tub/bed); note how much assistance is required and note any assistive devices used. Assess wheelchair (power and/or manual) mobility, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Observe patient’s gait; note any need for an assistive device for gait, such as crutches or walker. Indicate if there is a need for referral to physical therapy Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Hand function -ABILHAND-Kids  – parent-reported  questionnaire of manual ability in children with CP that may be useful in assessing children with unilateral CP. Responsiveness to changes was established in a clinical trial setting(48) -Bimanual Fine Motor Function Scale–  assesses hand function -Manual Ability Classification System (MACS)(22) – classification of how persons with cerebral palsy use their hands during daily activities -Computerized Peg Moving Task(1) –assessment of hand function in which patient moves 10 pegs one by one to an opposite hole -Melbourne Assessment of Unilateral Upper Limb Function (MAUULF)(7) – assesses upper limb function in children with spasticity -Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(15) –assesses hand function using common objects and tasks  -Assisting Hand Assessment (AHA)(16) –assesses spontaneous use of assisting hand during bimanual tasks for children aged 18 months to 12 yearsDetermine Developmental Disregard (VOAA-DDD)–  a video observation assessment of the overall duration and frequency of use of the affected upper limb during bimanual tasks(28) -Developmental disregard (DD) is the discrepancy between capacity and performance of the affected upper limb in a subset of children with unilateral CP. Researchers of an electrophysiological RCT conducted in the Netherlands found DD to be associated with increased cognitive load during dual-hand  performance tasks(39) -In the VOAA-DDD,  a child is videotaped while performing two bimanual standardized tasks, stringing beads and decorating a muffin, and trained therapists assess the video recording for grasp, hold, and release in conjunction with frequency and duration of the use of the affected upper limb(28) -Dutch researchers established the VOAA-DDD  as a valid and reliable tool for children 2.5 to 8 years of age(28) -Box and Blocks Test (BBT) – assessment of grasp, release, and dexterity involving moving as many blocks as possible to the opposite half of a box in 1 minute –Movement -Comparative Analysis of Performance – Motor (CAP-M)(2) – task analyses of a relevant task to provide the therapist with specific information, allowing the therapist to set goals and plan intervention -Upper Extremity Fugl-Meyer  Assessment – standardized assessment of motor impairment, volitional movement -Motor Activity Log(17) – self-report  of amount of daily limb use and quality of limb function –Tone -Modified Tardieu Scale of Muscle Spasticity(2) -Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) of muscle spasticity(2)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Children with CP generally have muscle weakness. Manual muscle testing (MMT) may be difficult due to age, cognitive development, or presence of abnormal tone or coordination; therefore, strength can be assessed through observation of functional activities and movements against gravity or in a gravity-eliminated  position (e.g., seated shoulder flexion or side-lying  shoulder flexion). Note any abnormality or asymmetry –Results of a 2014 systematic review indicate that the best device to measure grip strength is the Jamar dynamometer. For other muscle groups, handheld dynamometry is recommended(35) Neuromotor development –PDMS-2  – standardized assessment of gross and fine motor skills in children from birth to 5 years of age –BOT-2(14) – standardized assessment of motor skills in children aged 4 years and older –Test of Infant Motor Performance (TIMP) – standardized assessment of motor control and organization of posture in infants 32 weeks gestational age to age 4 months
observation inspection palpation includi: Observe spine; adults with CP may have scoliosis, which may cause pain(5)
Assess skin; check for any areas of redness, especially in children who are not mobile •Oral mechanism exam and related tests
Perform cranial nerve testing of cranial nerves IX, V , X, and XII for tongue, swallowing, gag reflex, and oral motor function as it relates to feeding •Palpation
Palpate muscles for atrophy or hypertrophy •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations)
Assess perception: children with spastic CP may have difficulty with visual motor precision and figure reproduction(1)
Perceptual deficits may impact motor function(1)
-Luria-Nebraska  Neuropsychological Test Battery(1)  measures verbal production, speech perception, nonverbal auditory perception, and visual-spatial  skills
-Ayres Southern California Sensory Integration Tests (Ayres SCSIT)(14)  assesses visual perception, kinesthesia, and graphesthesia
-Test of Visual-Motor  Integration (VMI)  copying forms/shapes of varying difficulty/complexity
-Test of Visual-Perceptual  Skills (TVPS)  tests visual memory, visual discrimination, visual-spatial relationship, form constancy, figure ground, visual closure

Handwriting skill in children with CP is significantly correlated with upper extremity speed and dexterity, proprioception, bilateral coordination, visual and spatial perception, and visual-motor  organization(14)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess posture in sitting and standing, noting any abnormalities. Assess patient’s posture in wheelchair seating system. Children with CP are at high risk for developing postural deformities(51,53) –Spinal deformity can occur in patients with CP (prevalence 20–25%)(8) -Scoliosis with increased thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis -Scoliotic patterns(8) -Group 1 curves –single  thoracic curves and lumbar curves with a level pelvis -Group 2 curves – C-shaped  collapsing curves, associated with pelvic obliquity; may or may not involve the sacrum -Lumbar lordoscoliosis -Isolated sagittal spinal deformity – rare, but may coexist with scoliosis(8)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess both active and passive ROM in all extremities using goniometric measurements as appropriate. Note any asymmetry or abnormality. Children with CP often have limited active/passive ROM in upper and lower extremities Reflexes –Assess for persistence of primitive reflexes Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI)(10) –WeeFIM(10) –COPM(13) –Quality of Upper Extremity Skills Test (QUEST) –Gillette Functional Assessment Questionnaire (FAQ) –Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS)(11)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Sensory discrimination such as tactile discrimination, stereognosis –Assess for deficits in sensory processing, such as increased or decreased sensitivities to stimuli, increased or decreased activity levels, problems with attention or self-regulation.  Can use Sensory Profile
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –GMFCS(4) –assesses the degree of activity limitation in children with CP -Provides gross motor development curves for each classification level, representing the average pattern of gross motor development of patients with CP –ICF-CY(18) – classifies and describes functioning, disability, and health in children and adolescents with all kinds of diseases or conditions -Part 1 – Body functions (b), Structure (s), Activities and participation (d) -Part 2 – Environmental factors (e), Personal factors (pf) -Properly identifying the patient’s needs in various levels of function allows for multidisciplinary collaboration and communication between the family, patient, and all healthcare professionals involved in the rehabilitation of the patient –Manual Ability Classification System (MACS)(19) –assesses and classifies how children with CP use their hands in daily life -Level 1 – handles objects easily and successfully -Level 2 – handles most objects but with somewhat reduced quality and/or speed of achievement -Level 3 – handles objects with difficulty; needs help to prepare and/or modify activities -Level 4 – handles a limited selection of easily managed objects in adapted situations -Level 5 – does not handle objects; has severely limited ability to perform even simple actions –Zancolli classification of deformities in the spastic hand(20)  –Health-related  QOL measures -Child Health Questionnaire (CHQ)(4,18) -Health Utilities Index (HUI)(18) -Caregiver Priorities and Child Health Index of Life with Disabilities (CPCHILD)(18) -Cerebral Palsy Quality of Life Questionnaire for Children (CPQOL)(18) -DISABKIDS CP-module(18) -Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory—CPmodule (PedsQL-CP)(18)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving)Children with CP may demonstrate problems with short-term  memory and working memory.(1) They may also demonstrate deficits in attention and inhibition, depending on location of brain injury.(1) Refer to speech therapy or neuropsychology as appropriate –California Verbal Learning Test – Children’s Version(1) –Lowenstein Occupational Therapy Cognitive Assessment(14)

other: Use caution when using constraint-induced  movement therapy (CIMT), as it can increase the risk of falls, reduce independence, and increase frustration for child when constrained(21)
Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies
Follow physician guidelines and recommendations for fluid and food intake for children with swallowing difficulties
Check for redness and skin irritation when splinting, providing seating/mobility, or using positioning devices
Hippotherapy should only be used by therapists who have specialized training

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Need for treatment is specific to areas of patient deficit that impact independence in self-care and school tasks. Examples of need for treatment would be difficulties with feeding, dressing, functional mobility, or school participation Results of a study from Canada indicate that most children and adolescents with CP received one or more rehabilitative therapy services (occupational therapy, physical therapy, speech-language pathology, psychology, special education). Individuals with greater motor or cognitive impairments were more likely to receive a greater number of therapy services within a school-based  setting(36)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Motor delay without specific neurological signs(22) Hypotonia in association with intellectual disability-1(22) Spinal cord damage(22) Hydrocephalous(22) Brain tumor(22) Metabolic disease(22) Motor problems of cerebral origin in spina bifida(22) Traumatic brain injury (TBI)
prognosis: Neurological deficits in CP are nonprogressive, and performance can improve over time(51,52,53,54)

Life expectancy is reduced according to the number and severity of impairments and by lower-quality  care(53,54,55) –Most individuals with CP survive to adulthood –Impairments that negatively affect life expectancy include -reduced mobility -poor feeding status -severe scoliosis -recurrent aspiration -intractable seizures

Prognosis depends on the child’s IQ, severity of motor deficits, and degree of incapacity(33) –Patients with mild CP may improve with age –Many children with normal intellect have normal lifespans and lead productive lives –Aspiration pneumonia and other infections are the most common cause of death

Authors of a 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis  examined the most frequently studied outcomes, health status, activities, and participation, in adults with CP(56) –65% experienced pain –58% were ambulant –65.5% had little or no limitation in manual ability –18% had tertiary education –39% were employed –29% lived independently
Results of a study suggest that over half of school-aged  children and adolescents with CP attend regular schools, with 41% of these requiring some degree of special education services(36)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist SLP Vision therapist Adaptive technology specialist Orthotist Physiatrist Orthopedic surgeon Social worker Neuropsychologist Dietician Resource specialist/special education teacher
other considerations: In accordance with the ICF-CY ,  occupational therapy assessments should emphasize levels of activity and participation, rather than the level of impairment, of the person with CP(2,29)
treatment summary: There are a variety of therapeutic treatment intervention techniques used by occupational therapists in the management of individuals with CP –A bottom-up  approach to treatment involves remediation of components of movement, such as muscle tone, strength, and ROM –A top-down  approach to treatment involves working directly on a functional activity/goal in context -Task-oriented  training can improve manual dexterity, fine motor skills, and age-appropriate  functional activities(37) -Top-down  interventions demonstrate greater clinical gains than bottom-up  interventions, based on a large systematic review involving all types of occupational interventions for children with a range of disabilities, including CP. Some examples of these interventions include bimanual training, CIMT, Cognitive Orientation to (daily) Occupational Performance (CO-OP),  goal-directed  training, social skills training, and task training(64) –Sensory integrative approach -Children with CP may do better with motor tasks when provided with sensory information. For example, children with CP may have better ROM when banging a drum than when doing the same action without the drum or drumstick(1)

Parent education/intervention –Parental involvement with occupational therapy is effective and worthwhile. Occupational therapy should focus on family-centered  care(64) –A parent-run  occupational therapy CP home program may improve function in children with CP and may also improve parent satisfaction(13) -Based on an Australian study involving 36 school-aged children with CP (ages 4–12) -Subjects were randomly assigned to occupational therapy home programs for 8 weeks, 4 weeks, or to a control group -The occupational therapy home programs consisted of establishing collaboration between parents and therapist, setting goals together, selecting therapeutic activities focused on achieving goals, providing support to parents, and evaluating

desired outcomes and outcome measures: Increased independence in self-care  skills, including feeding, dressing, bathing, toileting, and mobility–PEDI, WeeFIM, COPM, QUEST, FAQ AMPS
Achievement of developmental milestones–PDMS-2,  BOT-2,  TIMP
Improved motor control, coordination, and tone–General Movements Assessment, CAP-M,  Upper Extremity Fugl-Meyer  Assessment, Motor Activity Log, MAS

Improved fine motor skills for self-care  and schoolwork–Bimanual Fine Motor Function Scale, MACS, Computerized Peg Moving Task, MAUULF, Jebsen-Taylor  Hand FunctionTest, AHA, VOAA-DDD,  ABILHAND-Kids,  BBT, Modified Nine-Hole  Peg Test
Improved functional balance, ROM for self-care  and schoolwork–BOT-2,  PDMS-2,  PBS, goniometry
Maximize participation in school and community activities–CHQ, PedsQL-CP,  CPCHILD, CPQOL

maintenance or prevention: Preterm infants (< 33 weeks gestational age) who are at high risk for CP should be screened formally by a skilled pediatric therapist or pediatrician for developmental motor delay. Motor milestones should include the following: rolling over from prone to supine, rolling over supine to prone, sitting with and without arm support, crawling, and cruising
Occupational therapy support to patient and family as functional independence skills change
It is important to follow through with any recommendations made by therapists for home program to maximize child’s functional potential

In a 2014 Canadian study of 91 school-aged  children and 167 adolescents with CP, 53.2% of children and 57.5% of adolescents were in regular schools; however, 41% of these students required special education resources. The remainder of these students were in special education schools. 84.6% of school-aged  children and 68.1% of adolescents were receiving  at least one rehabilitation service. Physical and occupational therapies were the most often prescribed in the school setting. Services were primarily weekly for the children and weekly or on a consultative basis for adolescents(30)
